content.description: A wandering route in the middle of the cliff. start at the height of the land clipping a fixed pin. Follow the zig zagging bolts till your under the roof. Traverse under the roof clipping these bolts with long draws to prevent heinous rope drag. Traverse right till in the left facing corner, clip the hidden bolt inside the "crack". Climb the corner and right wall, pull over to the anchor.
content.protection: Mostly bolts and one pin, bring two extendable draws. Some might want a few small to medium cams.  two bolt anchor.
content.location: Follow the trail right across the stepping stones and up a few feet to the next "platform". This route starts on the left of the platform at the height of the land.

content.description: A fun bolt line with thought provoking moves, following the blunt arete. Follow the bolts up the arete, till a overlap is encountered. Pull the overlap doing some tricky moves. Climb the slab aiming for another overlap with the "sharks fin". Pull over the overlap to the right of the fin to the anchor.
content.protection: bolts, maybe a rack of stoppers for after the overlap if your not into slab.
content.location: The arete on the right side of the " platform". also is the right of the two close bolt lines. If climbing with a 60 meter rope you can do some easy dirt down climbing if your rope wont reach on rappel.

content.description: Same start as Mr Smee's 5.8. Mantle off the ground and climb the finger crack right. Instead of climbing the hand crack above keep right and climb the right facing dihedral to the shared anchor.
content.protection: small to BD #3    two bolt anchor
content.location: From where the trail meets the cliff go left and uphill on the trail. Farthest left route on the cliff. look for the cracks.

content.description: start with a mantle, and climb the finger crack to the right. climb the hand crack above the finger crack and then slab your way to the anchor.
content.protection: small to BD #2, two bolt anchor
content.location: From where the trail meets the cliff go left and uphill on the trail. Farthest left route on the cliff. look for the cracks.

content.description: This route climbs the big left facing corner on the right side of the crag. Climb the slab to a small overlap, protect and pull into the corner. Clip some bolts and place some gear climbing the corner till the overlap is reached. Clip bolt and pull over overlap to the right. Slab up and pull through another overlap with a grove in it. Climb the thin slab with bolts and gear to anchor.
content.protection: Bolts, nuts and cams from small to BD #1. This pitch protects well if you look for the gear. If you miss some it can feel quite run out.
content.location: Currently the farthest route to the right. You can't miss the huge left facing corner.

content.description: To the right of Tinkerbell Hell are two bolt lines. I've gotta Crow is the left one. A fun slabby route capped by a cool overhanging alcove feature. It is helpful to clip the bolt at the base of the alcove with a long draw.
content.protection: All bolts. One long draw and two bolt anchor.
content.location: 20 feet right of Tinkerbell Hell and the left of the two close bolt lines.

content.description: The first route you see when the trail comes to the cliff. Follow bolts up the slab to a stance 25  feet up. Go off the stance to the left following bolts and aiming for the left end of the big roof. Pull around the left side of the roof and follow slab into the low angle to the corner to the anchor above.
content.protection: Mostly bolts but a few small cams and nuts are a good idea. Two bolt anchor.
content.location: Starts where the trail meets the cliff. Notice the bolts on the smooth slab. Make sure to knot your end with a 60 meter rope when rappelling.

content.description:
This area was subject of a forest fire in the autumn of 2017. You may encounter charred trees and BEWARE OF NYLON RAP ANCHORS ON TREES and BOLTS. The prudent will replace!.

 Update 2019 -   Since the fire this entire area has seen extensive clean up and trail work by Jamie Cunningham and local climbers and most routes are climbable including all three pitches of Black Tourmaline.  The crags are all open now and expect to find lots of new growth ferns and small shrubs along the trail as nature takes care of the fire damage.  Jamie recommends folks bring in loppers (or hand clippers) and a small saw for any further trail and route maintenance. It also appears (to me) most bolts have been replaced...at least they all looked new to me on Lower Patina Wall in Sept 2019.

 The newest edition to the Lost River Crags. The farthest walk in from the lot, but we are in it for adventure aren't we? Neverland hosts seven routes at this time, and more to come. Mostly a bolt protected area but most routes require a bit of gear as well. All routes are bolted ground up on lead. This is very close if not partly on Lost River reservation property so keep a low profile.
